Know this if you like to eat early. The hotel restaurant accommodated the early eaters too. It had easy access to transportation. The metro was very affordable and easily traversed. Granted you are not staying across from the Eiffel Tower, you are not paying that price either. The Tower and museums etc are easily accessible on the metro in 10-15 min. Warning about taixs from the airport to your hotel! You might get charged way more than it actually costs. You will get approached by people wanting to give you a ride to your hotel if you do not have this travel accomodation already set up. Negotiate this price! A 45-50 euro trip may cost you 75-85 euros.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent Marriott service as per usual”
Reviews.Author: RickPorgera
Reviews.Content: I bought some (really cheap, as it turned out) Cultuzz vouchers on E-Bay well before I travelled to Paris this time around, and booked a 4-day -tay based on the vouchers (2 x 2 nights, including breakfast). As one can expect, the service here is exceptional, and the rooms are as comfy as any Marriott on the planet. Views from the rooms can be a tad ordinary...but that's not the reason anyone goes to Paris is it..? It's extremely handy to the Metro stations, and the RER, for travel further afield, as the furthest you would have to walk in any direction is a city block, and voila, you have transport to wherever you want to go. Staff at the hotel (despite my cheap-ness with the voucher thingies) are as polite and helpful as can be, and there is no hint of condescension. Breakfast is beyond belief with all the french flavours you can try..or just an English breakfast if you prefer. It can get a tad crowded if you leave your breakfast a little late (say 08:00-ish) but the staff will always find room for you in a delightful environment. Plenty of bistros/pizza/cafe outlets within easy walking distance if you wanted to try something different, but we tried them all, and eventually resigned ourselves to the fact that the restaurant at the hotel has them all beat anyway. I would have no problems staying at this fine hotel anytime again...with or without benefit of discounted vouchers. We were both very impressed.

Reviews.Title: “Great hotel but a bit far from city center”
Reviews.Author: JerseyHiker
Reviews.Content: We stayed there mid-September 2007, at the end of a three-week trip through France. The hotel is right by two metro stops, so it is convenient in that sense, but it is a very long walk to the big tourist attractions – our advice is to take the metro! But the location was not a problem for us since we had been in Paris before. Since I am a frequent traveler who stays mostly at Marriott hotels in the USA, we stayed there on “Marriott points”, and our rate included free breakfast in the concierge floor. They served a terrific continental breakfast, but if you are a really early riser, you’ll find the staff busy re-stocking the refrigerators (emptied out by guests the evening before) before setting out the food. Having access to the Concierge floor meant we could also have beer, wine, and snacks in late afternoon and well into the evening. It is a beautiful, modern, spacious hotel, with excellent service, overall. We used their business services without problem for some papers we needed printed from our laptop computer. We had a room on the 19th floor, which afforded us a great panoramic view of Paris, but the view from our room of the Eiffel tower was blocked by the Montparnasse tower a couple of miles away. Oh well. Valet parking is available for an additional charge; just bring your car to the front of the hotel by the main door. WiFi is available, some free, some not, depending on your deal with the hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Good business type hotel”
Reviews.Author: mathildexl
Reviews.Content: We had a large comfortable Marriott quality room (1028) and a good breakfast included in our package deal. The staff is friendly and helpful. The location is good, close by the subway station Glaciere. With the Orlybus (6,10Euro) you have an easy acces to the Orly airport, with the busstop right in front of the hotel. We would stay there again.

Reviews.Title: “Pleasant stay”
Reviews.Author: tybo
Reviews.Content: we stayed here for 4 nights. it was the end of our trip and we had been on the road for 5 weeks. we just wanted something familar and nice. location was great for the metro.paris is very easy to get around with the metro. we stay at marriotts alot and have never had a bad experience. the rooms were great and the bar was great. not a truly french experience but all you have to do is leave the hotel .all in all a great stay

Reviews.Title: “Best hotel stay I've every had”
Reviews.Author: solotraveler916
Reviews.Content: Booked under $100 on priceline. Everything available for ease of travel, touring, business and comfort. Best tip: when you check in, ask to upgrade and for a top floor "avec un vue." For 45E per night, you get access to the business lounge, really like a giant living room with round the clock (practically) stocked refridgerators of all the soda, beer, juices you can drink, espresso and coffee machines with 6 choices of style, fruit, cookies and full breakfast along with appetizers (really a meal) at night and desert later. You also get internet in your room (normally 20E a day). Second best tip: bring your long underwear and a credit card with a chip in it (I got mine from American Express). A kiosk of rentable VELIBS (Velo + liberte) bikes are around the corner (one of 750 kiosks around the city and thousands of bikes). For 5E for a week, I checked out a bike each morning and rode all over Paris in the new bike lanes/bus lanes. Faster than traffic. Cute 3 speeds, with baskets and a lock. Cute bell too. Stayed over Christmas; lots of Americans stay here and staff speaks English if you need it. Excellent, top of the line gym, especially for Paris, in the hotel. Although geared towards an American tourist/business person, very French in modern style and complete graciousness of staff. (2 pictures of my bike/kiosk attached).

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful & convenient”
Reviews.Author: Desserie
Reviews.Content: After much searching through TripAdvisor and other sites, we finally decided to book our week long stay in Paris at the Marriott Rive Gauche. It was everything we had hoped it would be: comfortable, with outstanding hotel staff, and convenient access to the metro. The room (large by Paris standards) was well appointed with lovely wood furniture in the bedroom and a granite countertop in the bath, very clean and well maintained. The bed was almost too comfortable, made it difficult to get up in the morning! Reception staff all spoke English, were extremely accommodating (especially when we requested different rooms farther from the elevator when they were nearly full; Tania was fabulous), and the concierges were all wonderful. Gerard recommended a patisserie just a few blocks from the hotel that had the best pastries in the world (and it was next to a fabulous chocolatier/macaroon shop). The hotel breakfast was excellent though pricey at 24 euros, so we feasted most days on incredible baguettes from the pastry shop and cheese from a nearby grocery store. The metro at nearby Denfert-Rochereau gave us quick and easy access to all of Paris, and when we chose to use taxis it was a quick and reasonably priced ride. As others have said, the hotel is located in a residential neighborhood, but as such it was quiet and a pleasure to return to at night. We actually preferred to be among the locals instead of in the midst of tourists in the center of Paris. Price was great through the Marriott web site, and we never would have gotten a hotel nearly as nice for the price this close to the sites of Paris. We would stay there again in a heartbeat!

Reviews.Title: “comfy beds!”
Reviews.Author: chi-towngirl79
Reviews.Content: after spending a week traveling through germany and luxembourg, it was nice to sleep in the fluffy beds. the location is not completely central but metro stop is close by and some of the sights are within walking distance (15-20 minutes). we had breakfast at the hotel every morning. the breakfast/brunch buffet is excellent!

Reviews.Title: “Good Service, Decent Business Amenties -> Great for the Price”
Reviews.Author: Two-Wheel_Traveler
Reviews.Content: I spent a long weekend in Paris and needed something reasonably priced with good business amenities in the room. Usually, I enjoy small/quaint hotels in 15th, but in this case I needed a more predictable hotel. This one was pretty much perfect for that. Now, if you're looking for local ambiance in a very "French" hotel, this probably isn't what you're looking for. Contrary to other reviews, it is in fact very Parisian. This hotel was built in the 70s or early 80s, I suspect, and is typical Parisian construction of the time. I'd compare the building to the old Nikko in the west part of Paris. It's built with the 70s concept of style and function. A concept that is best left in the past, but alas, Paris has quite a few buildings from that era that remain with us. Zoning and regulation make it difficult to tear down these unfortunate edifices. So we make do. Marriott took the property over a couple of years ago, according to the staff. They overhauled it and it's pretty consistent with the solid level of amenities and good service that I've come to expect from the chain. The lobby is still horrid (again, 70s architecture), but for what it is, it's ok. For the price (Euros175/night for king size bed) it was very good. Location is ok, being near St. Jacques metro station. Rue St. Jacques itself is chock-a-block with hotels and not particularly memorable, aside from being typical Paris. But the metro makes easy access to the rest of the city. I actually spent very little time in the area, using it mostly to sleep and work in the hotel, but otherwise hanging out with friends elsewhere. The general condition of the hotel is excellent. Everything is nearly new. The elevators, room furnishings (TV, coffee maker, etc.) were functional and worked properly (not always the case, especially in less than top-tier hotels). The bed was very comfortable with respectable linens, which is standard for Marriott. Bathroom was well appointed with a deepish bathtub. The toilet was in a separate closet from the bath area, as is standard in much of France. Breakfast was good and brought promptly, even a little early, which is fine for me. Food in general was better than average for what one usually gets with room service. The business functionality of the room was excellent. This is why I chose a Marriott hotel. Internet and desk space were good and allowed doing work, making phone calls, etc. I had room to hook up my MP3 player to speakers. My only minor complaint is that my voltage adapter needed to do double duty for both my phone and laptop as the power outlets did not include a US-style outlet. Marriott hotels usually include a US style outlet at or near the desk. Not a big deal, as long as you carry an adapter. Alternatively, the concierge has adapters for a small returnable deposit. Bottom line, this is a great hotel for what it is. I'd even return to it for a week of time off in Paris if the price were right. Certainly 175 Euros is great for what you get. Would I rather that it was chic or "un hotel francais typique", of course I would. But then it would be twice the price, I'm sure.

Reviews.Title: “4 Star for B&B bucks”
Reviews.Author: agedude
Reviews.Content: Booked on Priceline for $85 and was happy to get the deal. Hotel is in the Southeast Corner of the Monparnasse district, close to the Catacombs. Renovated business hotel in a quiet residential neighborhood. Close to two Metro stations (St Jacques and Glacerie, the latter is closer) and a fifteen minute walk from the Denfort RER station. The Denfort is on the Orly, CDG airport line B so you can take the train to the hotel. Nice lobby and very friendly if young staff. Restaurants in the hotel are expensive and cater to those on expense accounts or large per diem (lots of airline crews). There are many restaurants close by to ranging from fast food (pizza, Kebabs) to decent dining. Not close to main attractions, but I walked from hotel to the Louvre and I'm old and fat. Room was great, large with incredibly comfortable king-sized bed. I asked for an upper floor for a view and was put on the 15th with a great view of the Parthenon, Val de Grace, and the Sacre Cour. Only problem was room stayed too hot for my taste (wife agreed). I had the room thermostat cranked to cold but I think the heat from the lower floors makes the upper ones stuffy. Can't open windows so slept above the covers every night. Can't imagine getting a better deal at the price and would have given 5 stars except for the heat.

Reviews.Title: “just okay”
Reviews.Author: sftravelor
Reviews.Content: my husband and i stayed here in september for several nights. we booked the trip last minute and found a lot of hotels sold out so found a pretty good deal here. we have seen the tourist sights before so location did not matter as much. in addition, my husband is diamond (or whatever top status is) at marriott so figured it was a good bet. The location: right near a metro stop and in a cute neighborhood. If this was my first time to paris i def. would not stay here, but since it wasn't the location was perfectly fine. The issue for me here was really the staff. I don't mind a few problems, it is just non stop problems the entire stay that bother me..... and there were quite a few here. when we checked in the elevator didnt work to our floor. finally we were told to just take it to another floor, and walk down/up. not a problem, except we had all of our luggage and no one to help us (or anyone else) out. there was also a lot of construction going on so this forced us to walk through the stairwells as they were being painted (which i am sure the people painting were not to happy about). after we checked in i decided to shower (the bathroom set up is a bit odd based on other posts but just move your stuff so it does not get wet), amazingly a hotel staff member walks right into our room . no knock, no apology (did i mention i was about to get in the shower). YIKES!! i yelled quickly in english (i forget french in a panic) and they left, my husband and i didn't get a good look at the person. i had forgot to put the deadbolt on(my bad) but usually there is a knock!!! what else.......fridge never worked even though we called about 5 times, mirror fell off the back of the door and the maintenence man yelled at me becuase i didn't call soon enough about it?? it was not my fault we were out. the executive lounge was doing a photo shoot for a brochure so all but ignored everyone in there for days--the amount of garbage they allowed to pile up on all the tables and counters each day was a bit embarrasing..... no free internet (just to use for like 5 mins.) in the executive lounge--they had the computers, and first day we could use it, but after that could not even check for a minute. free internet was something they were "trying out". trying to get help in the executive lounge or from a staff member next to impossible. in a nut shell, if you have been to paris before and can get a good rate and don't mind a bit of staff issues this is probably fine. if you are looking for a romantic getaway or are visiting for the first few times--best to avoid.

Reviews.Title: “Nice hotel”
Reviews.Author: MauiWorldTravelers
Reviews.Content: We stayed 3 nights at the Paris Marriott RGH. It's located along one of the many Metro stops, and is pretty near to all the famous Paris sights. The room was comfortable (the bed was very comfortable!), but the bathroom was a little weird. Instead of having the shower on the same level as the rest of the bathroom, you are elevated about a foot or so, and a very small glass partition (runs about 1/4 the length of the tub) tries to keep the water inside the tub, but doesn't. The bath amenities were actually nice for a hotel (lemon scent). Restaurants surrounding the hotel weren't good at all; venture out!

Reviews.Title: “Nice hotel despite hotel staff”
Reviews.Author: logcolb
Reviews.Content: We had two rooms for four days at the Marriott Rive Gauche in September 2007. The hotel is typical Marriott. It is comfortable, clean, stylish decor and very comfortable bedding. The bed is seamless with terrific linens and pillows. The rooms very large by european standards and the bathroom, while a little strangely laid out, is very good. If you are looking for charming and quaint this is not the hotel for you. If you are looking for comfortable and Marriott quality you will be happy here. We booked the hotel on Priceline for $175 per night which I think is an excellent price for Paris and the quality of the hotel. The hotel is in a decent neighborhood, but if you are looking for the charm of the West Bank this hotel is a couple of metro stops too far out. The hotel is located between two metro stops with an easy two block walk to metro. The metro is excellent and will take you anywhere with ease and inexpensively (get the 10 trip book or the day or three day pass). My complaints have more to do with the hotel staff. It took us four days and numerous calls to get a reading light bulb replaced. We also asked the desk about getting a calling card. We were told that the hotel offered sold one, however, you could not use it in your room, but had to use it in the pay phone on the street. Since it was raining and we needed paperwork for our call, this was not an acceptable solution. I suppose Marriott would rather inconvenience their guests rather than give up their overpriced profits from using your room phone for long distance calls. If you need a calling card you need to go a couple of blocks to a convenience store. Some of the staff was very helpful and friendly and other staff was less so. If you are looking for a tasteful and comfortable hotel with good access to metro this is a great hotel, depending on the price you pay. If you are looking for quaint and charm look elsewhere.

Reviews.Title: “Not Your Typical Paris Hotel”
Reviews.Author: imagine71
Reviews.Content: The bright side is that the hotel has been recently renovated and that it shows. Rooms are immaculate with very comfortable bedding, though a little on the small side. All in all very nice. While I stayed there on business I would not chose the hotel for a leisure stay. It is a little out of the way of most tourist hot spots and very unpersonal. It's a very large convention style hotel having absolutely nothing of the charm one might associate with Paris. Given that there is a huge numer of small but great quality hotels in Paris that give you the Paris experience in terms of charme I would certainly go elsewhere for a private stay. That said, returning on business might surely be an option.

Reviews.Title: “Eh”
Reviews.Author: HomerJayNewYork
Reviews.Content: I just stayed at this hotel. It is not actually located in Montparnasse, but rather Denfert-Rochreau. This was not a major problem for me as I have been to Paris and France in general over 6 times. However, if you are new to Paris, this can pose a bit of a problem. There is very little to do in this area and you will inevitably need to use the Metro to get anywhere. I highly recommend the purchase of a Carte d'Orange weekly pass. (you will need a passport photo for this) I was there for 6 nights and will say that the Marriott is very clean and well kept. There is ongoing construction and improvement happening, so there may or may not be funny smells, noise, etc. All in all the room was very clean except for the time the cleaning lady left cleanser on the vanity and dirty pillow cases on our floor. I will say that the cleaning ladies have a nasty habit of waking you up at roughly 9:30 unless you have a "do not disturb" sign on the door. I can't be too critical of this, as i understand that they have a job to do. I never tried the room service, but the restaurant looked like an upscale brasserie. I doubt that the food would have been anything but good. I also recommend that you get to know the supermarkets. I bought chips and drinks, as it is very expensive in the minibar and in almost any paris venue. France is the land of 6 dollar cokes. As for the general staff, they all speak many different languages and are very friendly. The were always helpful and kind. In closing, there are a few things you should know: 1. Lots of Americans. It is a good place to meet people if you do not know French. 2. Mostly caters to business, so be aware that there are crowds of business people there at any given time. 3. Nice Gym, bring workout clothes if you like. 4. The trains stop running around midnight, so be wary of time. If you miss the last train, it is a long walk from central paris. 5. It is near Montparnasse, not in. If you use the Air France Bus from CDG, it is a long walk to the hotel. You will be better off using the Metro from Montparnasse station.

Reviews.Title: “Fantastic - Great Views - Phenomenal Metro Location”
Reviews.Author: amcdonald
Reviews.Content: SUPERB! The Marriott in Paris is a fantastic larger hotel and it's in a great location. Located very close to the Metro Line (3-4 minute walk at max) this place is unbeatable. I was very reluctant once I received my bid on Priceline ($110 - amazing for Paris) as I am use to staying in little hotels in the heart of cities. I was apprehensive to cancel my reservation in the 6th however once we arrived I was extremely impressed. After flying for 12+ hours and arriving in Paris (my husband's first trip), the Marriott was a great way to start our 2 week adventure. We were able to ease in to the European lifestyle and able to explore so many different areas of the city. The reason for this is the Metro - this metro line runs in the East-West direction whereas most other lines run North-South (look on the metro map) so we were able to transfer quite easily to other lines for all of our daily trips. In addition to the ease of the metro, the staff was superb. The concierge desk was extremely helpful in booking dinner reservations. Also, the view from the 16th floor was amazing. Very few hotels in Paris offer views of the city. Overall, I was so pleased with our stay - especially with Paris being our first city on our trip and at this price, it just can't be beat. We stayed in quaint places along the way so we were able to really experience Europe however for Paris, the Marriott is fantastic. Don't miss the Boulangerie across the main street from the Metro station down about two blocks. Breakfast every morning outside watching the world go by...ahhh...

Reviews.Title: “Good Experience”
Reviews.Author: Rhine-and-Roses
Reviews.Content: We travel to Paris a good bit and usually use smaller hotels that give more of a "feel" of Paris. We were unable to book a hotel we were happy with, so we decided to go with Marriott, which we used in Munich. It was a good stay, but you definitely had no idea you were in Paris from the room- could have been LA or Seattle. Everything except the view was good. We had wonderfully comfortable beds. The bathroom was fine, with no mold or mildew, although it was not ventilated. The placement of the sink was a little awkward. The toilet was separate, which is often the case in France. The room and hall were freshly painted and carpeted. The bed linens were great. The room had a large, remote tv, accessibility to the internet through the tv, as well as wifi and cable internet connections. Selection of French, English, German tv stations (maybe other languages, too- I didn't look beyond those three) There was no clock in the room, although you could get a wake up service. Rooms had safes and a small fridge (no mini-bar). There was an iron and ironing board. The staff were very friendly, even the poor guy I forgot to tip. Everyone greeted us warmly with each contact. We drove in and used the garage- valet parking. It was 20 Euro per day, secure and videotaped. Security was visible at the hotel, with three guys clearly watching the front at all times. They checked me instantly when I pulled up to see why I was in front of the hotel. There were also cameras about. I don't know if this was normal or because the World Cup Rugby matches started while we were there. We did not use the restaurants. Maid service was fast and good. The hotel is located between St Jacques and Glaciere metro stations. Both are on the same line. There are a number of small bistro/cafes in a few minutes walk. There is a small bakery within easy walk towards St Jacques metro, but I didn't think it was very good. This hotel's location is not in the middle of the tourist attractions, but it is quick to get to most places. Hope this gives you a good overview. We were happy with this hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Luxurious bedding”
Reviews.Author: yvrgirlToronto
Reviews.Content: My mother and I had a superb stay here. I had booked through Priceline $130 US per night x 2. The entire hotel is newly renovated. The beds are superbly comfortable and really, that is the most important thing as the hotel really is a pit stop overnight for the shopping you will do in this wonderful city. The breakfast is quite overpriced but convenient for a buffet. $24 euros pp. The reception ladies are very nice and helpful. Unfortunately, there is no pool. TIP: Take the N21 bus and use it like a city tour bus. Turn R out of the hotel and walk down to catch it under the bridge (beyond the Glaciere subway station where you can buy a carnet of 10 bus tickets for 11.50 Euro and ask for a pocket map). I find it better to see things on ground than underground. Hop off wherever you like. Go to St Michel for shopping, the Opera for more shopping at galeries lafayette and to see the National Opera structure. Visit the Luxembourg gardens for free.

Reviews.Title: “Loved the Marriott Rive Gauche”
Reviews.Author: Twinknie
Reviews.Content: Loved the Marriott Rive Gauche. Located in a quaint neighborhood, convenient to metro, and local shops and restaurants. Hotel recently renovated, very stylish, staff was friendly and helpful. Large convention hotel, still has a personal touch, and all the amenities to make for a very comfortable stay. Had a room on the 18th floor with an amazing view of Paris.

Reviews.Title: “I felt like a queen at Paris Rive Gauche”
Reviews.Author: BeckyCooper
Reviews.Content: Paris Rive Gauche Marriott deserves the star rating it receives. The lobby is inviting, staff are welcoming and accommodating, and it has a first class feel. There are good views from the windows. The beds are HEAVENLY just like all Marriotts! There is more than one place in the Rive Gauche to grab a cup of coffee or a drink. You can also fix a cup of coffee or tea in the room, or buy something from the mini-bar. A safe is in the closet for valuables. One of the things I really appreciated was a nice terry cloth robe. It would have taken its own carry-on to bring it from the States! I stayed here twice - the week between Christmas and New Year's in 2005 and 2006. St. Jacques Boulevard is beautiful. The Glaciere metro stop is across the street. There is a pharmacy nearby, a grocery store, and a spirits store down the street. Restaurants are up and down St. Jacques Blvd. Place d'Italie, with the only mall in Paris, is only a couple of metro stops away. It was nice to go shopping or sightseeing, and get back to the Rive Gauche to crawl in the nice warm heavenly bed. I would definitely recommend this hotel. Oh this Marriott still has smoking floors and the Concierge sells american cigarettes and free boxes of matches. You can also smoke with your drinks in certain areas of the hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Good value for our money”
Reviews.Author: Pebblie
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Marriott Rive Gauche for 2 nights in August 07. This hotel was great for the price we paid (80 Euros per night on Priceline). It met our expectations in almost all aspects. Nice lobby, friendly staff, comfortable room, good bathroom. The room wasn't big, though it was large by Parisian standards. We walked to Quartier Latin or the Louvre every day (30 mins - 1 hour) since the weather was gorgeous. Otherwise we could have taken the metro for a few stops. On the downside, we waited quite a while before getting that friendly service. And there were hairs in our fresh towels - something that should simply never happen in a 4-star hotel. Breakfast was overpriced but convenient. Our room faced the next building, but then we were never there, so we didn't mind. We had an excellent stay, but would probably have been a little disappointed if we had payed the full 4-star price.

Reviews.Title: “Value for money”
Reviews.Author: gaspar
Reviews.Content: I managed to get a deal booking at this hotel and travelling on the Eurostar from London. It looked good at €109 per night including breakfast. Our stay was for 3 nights (Mon-Thu) in the middle of August (slow month for such a Conference hotel). Location: 30 Minutes from Gare du Nord (Eurostar terminal) taking the RER and 2 underground stops. Underground station Glaciere is 2 minutes walking from the hotel. If you are not carrying much luggage is worth taking this route, otherwise taxis would cost over €20. The underground from Glaciere takes you to Les Champs Elisees and the Eiffel tower in less than 20 minutes. I also went to Le Pigalle and it took us 40minutes including changes. Notre Dame is 10 minutes away taking the RER. The Hotel is situated south of the river. If you like to venture in Paris (we had a friend as a guide) I reccommend the velib. They are "public bicycles". They are available next to the hotel and you can leave them everywhere in Paris. Hotel: This Marriott is a Conference Center previously owned by Sofitel. Marriott is refurbishing the rooms. Ours had already been done but there were decorating two other rooms on our floor. There was no noise, only paint smell in the corridors in the morning. The lobby is quite large, but the reception desk is not too big. There was a group checking in when we arrived and upon queueing we were taken to a side of the desk and bypassed the group. Although I booked with my credit card, it was again requested at check in and again at check out....... how many times do they need it? Get a map from the Concierge. They will also tell you the best way to get to different areas. Bar: Modern and quiet when we where there. Staff was friendly and chatty. Only but is that the small size of beer is advertised at 25cl but the glass is a 20cl (with the size mark). The barman topped up our glasses with a smile (I like being difficult, hehe) Room: We had been upgraded at check in. I imagine that this meant that we had a view. And what a view. 17th floor of the hotel looking at Paris (could see the Sacre Coeur). Otherwise the size of the room was average. Plasma screen in the room with internet connection (€25 per day!!) and pay per view movies with language option. The selection of channels is quite good, with international news channels in different languages. Minibar is well stocked and there is a safe in the room. The bathroom is ok, with the toilet on a different 'cupboard'. The bed was a Marriott standard, comfortable and with plenty of pillows. Summarising, not an amazing room, but very convenient for business people and the views make up for it. We didn't spend much time in it anyway. Breakfast: The breakfast room is situated on the second floor. Breakfast offering is quite large with both hot and cold buffets (hit and miss with the bacon, one day the chef had decided to overcook it, the next undercook it). There is a chef preparing eggs and omelettes. I must say she was always smiling and welcoming and very good with the omelettes. My wife decided to try the boiled eggs but they have only soft boiled (almost raw) or hard boiled (even the yolk is cooked). We asked for a medium boiled eggs but apparently this was not possible!! I cannot imagine why except maybe that the eggs are not cooked by a chef but by a machine. Paris is great and this hotel was great value for money. For my next stay I will keep on looking for good deals. I wouldn't pay more than I did to stay here.

Reviews.Title: “Nothing special”
Reviews.Author: Muscae
Reviews.Content: Marriott Rive Gauche is a business conference hotel, so if you're looking for a charming experience in Paris, this is not really what the hotel provides. It caters more to large tour groups or businesspeople. However, it does have some things going for it: clean and recently renovated, the famous Marriott beds, lovely view of the Butte Montmartre and Sacre Coeur, and a good breakfast spread. What I didn't like was that the rooms were extremely small, the location in the 14th arrondissement is quite remote, the soulless feeling of a conference hotel, and the tiny, windowless gym. Also, the staff weren't terribly well-trained: long waits at breakfast for coffee; they kept removing the extra bathrobe which we'd requested because there were 2 guests in the room; bottled sparkling water arrived without a bottle-opener. If you are using your Marriott points to redeem a holiday, as I was doing and as it seems most tourist guests to this hotel do, I would consider the Renaissance Vendome instead, which is a far better hotel in terms of quality and location, and only one category (Category 7) more expensive.

Reviews.Title: “Great Place to Stay in Paris”
Reviews.Author: MMiles
Reviews.Content: Booked this hotel for eleven days after reading all the recent reviews and changes that had taken place. The hotel is now a Marriott and not a Sofitel; the rooms have all been renovated but construction is still taking place on the second floor. It should be noted that it is also recognized as one of the largest business centers in Paris. There are 18 floors and easily over 750 rooms. The lobby is always bustling with tour companies, flight crews (looks like American Airlines is connected to them) and business people. I am no stranger to Paris and wanted something in one of the more "quiet" sections of Paris but not too far away from the action. This hotel was perfect for our needs. The lobby is grand with marble floors and you enter facing the 24 hr. Concierges who work around the clock for the patrons. Bellhops were courteous and always helpful; openning doors and hailing cabs. The service by all of the staff (overall) was remarkably good and helped to make the hotel feel more personable, even for its grand size. Room service was very attentive and even brought my son and I a panini after our airport shuttle disaster (see other postings on avoiding ATA Beauvais Shuttle) at 3:00 am. The food was hot and well prepared. While the offerings were limited at that hour - the fact we could still get anything to nibble was quite amazing. Our room was a standard to smaller size Marriott room - typical for large city hotels. The decor is much more Amercianized then French, but boasts almost a Scandinavian style "simplicity" on the first floor. My room did not have a great view, but I had also booked with a great rate from Priceline. The beds were simply unbelievable! Granted they were only twin (I think) but they seemed so much fluffier with all of the down comforters and 26"x26" down pillows... I digress. Anyway, the room has a small fridge with the usual $50 peanuts - but they do have a small space for personal goods. The safe in the room easily fit my laptop, some cash, cards, a camera, etc. Room service was a bit noisy early in the day - and unfortunately you can hear doors closing/slamming. This was not very noticable early in the vacation because our next door neighbors were teenagers who stayed out all night. But when a tourist group arrived that awoke each day at 6:00 am - I could hear the rumble- not terrible, but noticable. Maid service tolerated the days when we decided to "sleep in" until 11:00 and even waited to make up our room until after 1:00 pm on a day my son met up with a friend. The room design is a bit crowded when you first enter. The toilet is seperate from the main bathroom and is on your immediate left as your enter - something that works well for my son and I - but may make some feel claustrophobic for the toilet room is small. Next door is the main bathroom with strong water pressure and a full bathtub. The water did not drain well, but we solved this problem by simply removing the stoppers completely from the tub. The bathroom was nicey decorated with three angle mirrors and the usual assortment of shampoos, soaps, etc. (*Lather) Additional nice ammenities included a fluffy bathrobe with soft towels. Guests have the option to have linens changed daily by placing cards on the bed. Once, my bathrobe was not replaced and a simple call resulted in immediate service. As you exit the bathroom the closet is on your immediate left and was able to fit our two small carry-on size suitcases plus hang our clothing. A small bar top complimented the built in closet and the mini fridge was located beneath the small bar counter. The beds - well, I could go on forever about those beds. Usually, I do not sleep well in hotels because of lower back arthritis. I am a tall guy and not that old, but usually beds are a touchy matter for me. At home, I have the Swedish foam beds and usually have a tough time at hotels with inferior mattresses. However, these beds (while small) boasted a comfortable mattress, fluffy down mattress liner, clean white linens (including fresh duvets on all) and those square European down pillows. With a personal thermostat in the room set to a nice cool temperature and the ability to black out all daylight (two sets of shade options) - well, I slept like a log. It was great!!! A desk was located at the far end of the room with internet connections and an annoying black glass table top - I kept wanting to clean the fingerprints off. The low lying dresser crossed in front of the beds with a nice large flat screen tv. Of course, the only English speaking stations were news related or MTV which was strangely split between English and German. Spanish opportunties (I am multi-lingual) were also limited to news. The TV also acted as a Wake Up service and offered the usual online opportunities to access the internet from tv, etc. It should be noted the online bill service was not very accurate - and even at check out, the bill was difficult to decipher since they had itemized each drink and food in the restaurant, etc. The Concierges appeared to be knowledgeable and understood that I was not easily "sold" on the patent "tourist" places to eat or visit. We have been to Paris several times and travel on a regular basis a few times a year. Thus, we like to be advised of "off the path" sorts of places or unusal "day-to-day" Parisian type places. We used the Concierge station for numerous purposes and were overall very pleased. I am one of those who always tips and appreciates the advice a good "insider" can offer. Most were excellent - with one or two exceptions - however there were almost always two on duty during the daytime openning up your options if you did not like a particular advisor. Downstairs the hotel is still undergoing renovations and the beauty stores and boutiques were all closed as they were being relocated to the second floor. However, the restaraunt R'yves was very good - expensive, but not "over the top" prices. The food was excellent and offered much of the traditional French dishes (Tatare, etc.) with some creativity and excellent presentation. The decor is very modern and boast a changing light scheme that is very Scandinavian in design. The wait staff were all very attentive and while one young waitress made a mistake on one of my sons lunches, she also managed to "make a mistake' by giving him extra portions of ice cream for desert. All in all, it is a very warm and relaxed place and we enjoyed eating here. It is unusual layout to uncover about the restaurants in the hotel because there is a second floor restaurant that serves breakfast. Then, a small "cafe" that offers quick snacks and coffee right in front of the main restaurant which is R'yves. However, once you get the swing, it can become quite relaxing. We became wise to the layout (sadly later in the trip) and discovered that you could eat dinner at R'yves then go into one of the three lounges and watch tv on big leather sofas - or you could lounge on the sofas in the other lounge areas and have cafe or an after dinner drink with desert. It was like being in your own home! Down further is a computer room, but the prices are just too ridiculous to make this a viable option. All in all, the restaurant section is quite nice and offers a nice selection at a somewhat overpriced amount. Keep in mind though, it is much better than the terrible restaurants right outside and right next door. Beware that the local surrounding restaurants were not very good - the service and quality were particularly bad at the place right on the corner. An apparent tourist trap, the place offers terrible food and on one occassion when I complained about the steak, the waiter actually became rude with me! Buyer Beware - avoid the three restaurants right outside the hotel we both became ill on one and wasted an entire day trying to get the Immodium to kick in. We ate... the duck... Breakfast was available at the hotel and was quite nice - but cost $24 Euros per person - that was almost 30 USD at the time of my exchange. Of course, being in Paris means finding a nice little coffee place and some croissants. Unfortunately, I did not find anything close to the hotel and needed to go further. Breakfast was always an issue and we finally decided just cheaper and easier to buy our own from a little local patissere (bakery) the night before and then have them in the morning in our room. I had to forego my caffeine craze and wait until later in the day. The hotel is close to a pharmacy, dry cleaner (reasonable) and a few grocery stores. Options were open and this makes the hotel even more attractive. The hotel is also in the middle of two Metro stops (Glaciere or St. Jacques) - this is line 6 and connects with all the other lines. It paid to buy the five day Metro Visitors Pass which also got us a discount on the Open Tour *yellow. Everything was easy to access and convenient. My teenage son discovered that it is easier to take Glaciere heading out (the walk is downhill) but coming back to use St. Jacques - thus, the walk would also be downhill. Teenagers love convenience - he also noted that we passed several small stores that offered other fruits and goodies we might need for the room each day. The RER is close by and the hotel is in close walking distance to the Catacombes. This RER B train is direct to CDG and is a quick fifteen minute walk straight down the road from the hotel. Several good restaurants are also available in that area. Did I mention that the beds were super fluffy - and you will want to just run home and jump into them every time you come back! Other considerations - the room did have an iron and board. While internet access is available it is quite expensive ($8.95 euros per hour or $19.95 euros per day - a week was over $100 euros!). Don't use your Blackberry connection from home, because I just discovered this cost me over 100 USD - thus, your best bet for internet is to use one of the cafes or to do a better job then I did searching out the free local hotspots. My criticisms of the hotel are in the added costs - the restaurant, internet, drinks or anything "extra" will cost you more. Parking is over 20 Euro per day - but we did not bring a car and did not have this problem. However, it is important to note that the quality is also very good. Thus, while the R'yves is a bit pricey I think the quality of its food was far superior to the really bad places nearby. If you are looking for a solid US Standard 4 * Hotel, you will really be glad you booked the Rive Gauche - it is not a typical Parisian style hotel. It offers those nice comfort items and ammenities that are expected by a 4* and it strives to make the customer happy. I think a change in Management had helped make this hotel a keeper and we would certainly return there in the future. Happy Travels!!!

Reviews.Title: “Weekend Retreat”
Reviews.Author: charlo0521
Reviews.Content: We spent our first weekend in Paris at the Marriott Rive Gauche. The hotel was clean, excellent room, and service was above average. We didn't arrive until late that night, and room service only offered a sandwich and salad. Nothing else was open nearby. The location isn't in the heart of Paris, but no more than a 10-15 min Metro ride. It seems to be in a more residential or business area. Not touristy. But the hotel is located 2 blocks from the Metro station or you can ride the bus to see the sights. The bed was so comfy, neither of us wanted to leave! The breakfast buffet could have been better (runny eggs), but dinner was good. The staff was helpful with directions and things to do. Downtown was about a 12 Euro cab ride. I think next time we visit Paris, we would try to stay at a hotel closer to the action, so we could take advantage easily of the nightlife. We didn't want to factor an expensive cab ride in later that evening. However, I would recommend the hotel to others who may not be as concerned.

Reviews.Title: “Very nice and friendly stay!”
Reviews.Author: jackkathy
Reviews.Content: We stayed here two nights on 8/2-8/4. The hotel was very clean and the rooms large for Paris. Those Marriott beds are the most comfortable anywhere! The staff was very helpful and gave us a quick lesson about the Paris Metro. The location of the hotel was close to two Metro stops. Avoid the restaurant and room service which were very overpriced.

Reviews.Title: “Top-class business hotel in a good location”
Reviews.Author: Sabyasachi
Reviews.Content: I stayed with my wife at this marriott property in July 2007 for 2 nights in a junior suite. The hotel is located within 2-3 mins walk from two metro stations - very easy to reach any part of Paris from this hotel. The hotel is almost done with its renovation and it looks stunning once you step in. Every single hotel staff is highly spirited and would do anything in their capacity to delight you. This is the single most differentiating factor for this hotel - keeping aside spotless cleanliness all through the property, new rooms and furnitures, awesome breakfast, great location and neighborhood and everything else that you may expect from the brand Marriott. The rates are still low compard to its peers given that this hotel is on its way to re-establish in the market following the change of hand from Sofitel to Marriott. I highly recommend this hotel for business as well as family stay while in Paris.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent”
Reviews.Author: chess66
Reviews.Content: My family (wife and two children) stayed in one of the "Family suites" for over two weeks and were highly impressed with all aspects of this property (staff, rooms, friendliness, location, cleanliness, etc.) I travel at least 1/3 of the year, mostly in the U.S. and this is one of the nicest properties I've ever used. I stayed at three other hotels in Paris (Terrass, Concorde Montparnassee and LeMeriden Etolie) and this was at least an American star rating above these. I was especially impressed with the professionalism and friendliness of the staff. All of them! I'm not sure how they have been able to hire such a full crew of staff members with an obvious desire to please their guest and do the best at thier individual responsibilites as possible. From the doorman to the Guest Relations Manager, they all seemed to really enjoy their work and take pride in their area of responsibility and it shows in a superior overall product.

Reviews.Title: “Great experience”
Reviews.Author: AndrewIp
Reviews.Content: My wife and I celebrated our 10th yr anniversary in Paris this last month. We initially booked another hotel but decided to try this one since it's part of the Marriott family and we are using Marriott rewards for the stay. I have to say this is one of the best hotels I've stayed in (within the same class). The exterior of the hotel might not impress you. But in general the interior is very nice (since they had renovated 10 months ago). Our hotel room faces the front of the building so we have the city view (unfortunately the Eiffel Tower is blocked by a tall office building at the Montpamasse area). We have no trouble getting around since it's on the Metro line #6 which takes you to the Eiffel Tower. And it's easy to transfer to other Metro line as well. Make sure get a City map at the concierge. By the way the concierge is very helpful. They recommended a corner cafe called L'Alouette that's about 3 blocks away and the food over there is excellent (and the wait staff speak English). The hotel room is very modern and good size in Europe standard. The bathroom is good enough. Although I did not particularly like their shower design. The bed is comfortable (all Marriott standard) and the TV selection is great (lots of news, movies and music). The hotel restaurant is nice. We had one meal in the hotel so we could not give you any suggestion there. We ate at the cafe that's right next to the hotel and it's reasonable price (but the food selections are mainly for locals). It's not hard to get from the airport to this hotel just take RER line B all the way and walk about 6 minutes from the stop. I would not recommend riding the train with big luggages. Overall this is a great location to stay in. It's very convenient (Metro stops, "super"-market and stores within few blocks away).

Reviews.Title: “Great rooms at Marriott Rive Gauche”
Reviews.Author: name_screen
Reviews.Content: Stayed for the first time at the Marriott Rive Gauche for a weekend trip to Paris. Easy to find with a short walk from RER B Denfert-Rochereau; Metro Glaciere or St Jacques near hotel for easy navigation around the city. Rooms have been remodeled with comfortable beds, marble baths, flat screen TV, in-room safe, mini-bar with small place for guest's items, hair dryer, etc. Internet use is additional. I stayed on 16th floor with great view. Some floors are smoking, others are non-smoking, make sure to request your preference. Concierge is very helpful with recommendations & reservations.

Reviews.Title: “Comfortable and Convenient”
Reviews.Author: SouperK
Reviews.Content: We just returned from 4 nights at the Paris Marriott Rive Gauche and can sum it up in two words: comfortable and convenient. We were on the 16th floor and had a fabulous view of Paris, with the Sacre Coeur directly in front of us in the distance. Being my first trip to Paris, we spent most of our time at all the typical tourist sites, which were about 20 minutes away on the Metro. The only location that was a bit farther was the Montmartre/Sacre Coeur area, which took us about 30 minutes on the Metro (about 16 stops), but still not bad at all. The metro stop, Glaciere, is about a 3-minute walk from hotel. The neighborhood where the hotel is located has a cafe, pizza place, a pharmacy and a grocery store all within a few minutes walk. There are ice machines in the hallways of the hotel. Also, the mini bar has a small section cleared out where guests can put a few items, enough space for ham, cheese and some mayo from the local grocery for midnight snacks. (But don't move anything in the mini bar. It's computerized and if you move an item, you just bought it.) There's a restaurant in the hotel with a full breakfast bar and also a small coffee bar that stays open late. We came in around 11:15 p.m. one night and it was still open. We enjoyed our stay at the Paris Marriott Rive Gauche very much. It's extremely comfortable, clean, feels safe in a nice neighborhood, and lives up to the Marriott reputation.

Reviews.Title: “Now it's a real Marriott & definitely deserves its 4 stars!!”
Reviews.Author: Alain71268
Reviews.Content: Formerly managed by Sofitel, this property went through a huge renovation plan since it was re-named as a Marriott. The remodeling is now almost completed & offers travellers a great new experience ! You definitely feel the Marriott touch walking through the lobby . Very well appointed & renovated rooms offer visitors a great level of confort & intimacy (room size was not the largest I have seen in Paris but still acceptable). Furnitures are brand new , flat tv screen & fantastic bed matress! Breakfast restaurant was inaugurated when I was there & is worth a visit now! Continental breakfast costs 14 euros/ affordable in room service (21 euros for a burger). Location: you are in the middle of the 14th district which is a pleasant & safe residential area. RER B(station is just 6 min walk from hotel entrance) will take you to St Michel/St Germain in 5 minutes. Eiffel tower & Etoile (Champs Elysees) are both on the green line which is just opposite to the hotel. 45 min from CDG airport (direct RER train) & 15 min by bus to Orly. I have stay in many hotels in Paris over the last 12 months & would definitely put the Marriott rive gauche on top of my preferred hotel list.

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful experience!”
Reviews.Author: bubbzy
Reviews.Content: We stayed at this hotel the last weekend in April, 2007 on a quick 4 day trip to London and Paris. The hotel is currently under renovation, but that was not a problem for us. While off the beaten path, we enjoyed our stay. We stayed on the 9th floor and were not disturbed by the renovations. First, I must say that the hotel staff from the bellmen to the extraodinarily helpful Concierge staff were great. A majority of the staff spoke english and were able to provide the assistance we needed. While the hotel rooms were small, they were modern and very comfortable. I slept like a log my two nights there. The hotel, was directly on the green (#6) metro line, with one stop across the street and two others within 3 blocks. It was very accessible. From the hotel we were easily able to access the major sights. Note the Trocadero and Eiffel Tower were directly on the #6 route. We ate breakfast at the hotel. While not overly fancy it was a basic, good breakfast which got us prepared for our long sightseeing day. I was traveling with my mother and sister and we typically stay at Marriott properties. While not amenity laden, we found this hotel a great, comfortable gem for our time in Paris. I would definitely stay there again without hesitation.

Reviews.Title: “OK Hotel but not Memorable”
Reviews.Author: Andrea63
Reviews.Content: The hotel is located in a residential area. The front desk and restaurant service was great and the concierge was very helpful. He went out of his way to book an airport shuttle for us late Friday night for an early Saturday flight. Breakfast buffet was good and reasonably priced. Menu selections at the restaurant was very limited. The hotel is a conference center so there's lots of guests( 300 to 600) arriving and departing at different times- "Traffic Jam" in the elevator. Although newly renovated, the rooms are small (smaller than other Paris hotels we've stayed before, even for Marriott standards). The bathroom situation was terrible. The toilet is separate from the Tub and sink area. The toilet is so claustrophobic. It's basically a toilet in a little closet space. The room has an unpleasant smell. The hotel is undergoing renovation so be prepared to be awaken with banging noise at 7:30 AM. The housekeeper barges in your room at 8:00 AM on the dot. There is security inside and outside the hotel. The best thing about this hotel is it is right across the metro stations-Glaciere and Saint Jacques. It is so easy to get everywhere in Paris.

Reviews.Title: “wonderful experience”
Reviews.Author: secretagent2050
Reviews.Content: We stayed at this newly refurbished Marriott for the location, and new beds! The front desk help all speak English, and could not be any nicer! The rooms are new, and small by American Standards- but perfectly adequat. The beds make all the difference for a restful night sleep. Nice new bathrooms also. The location is quiet, and metro across street. Better value to stay out of the city center, and you still have to commute where ever you stay. Market up the street with fresh fruit and pastry. Only problem- only CNN in English on the tube! Very safe neighborhood, all the conviniences you need at this hotel. Don't hesitite to book this one- adding new features all the time-can't ever go wrong with the Marriott family!

Reviews.Title: “Great”
Reviews.Author: rcarany
Reviews.Content: I stayed here during the last two days of my Paris vacation. We stayed in one of the newly renovated rooms and it was very elegant. I loved the neighborhood, it wasn't touristy and it had a real down to earth feel. The treatment @ the hotel was great. Do the American buffet breakfast, its a tremendous deal. I would reccomend this hotel for the tail end of your trip once you've seen all the sights.

Reviews.Title: “Newly Renovated and much much better”
Reviews.Author: Kiwichan1
Reviews.Content: We previously stayed in this hotel about 18 months ago when it was owned by Sofitel and the hotel itself was nice and well located but the hotel room we were given was the worst I've ever stayed in. Since then, I had seen on Tripadvisor that the Marriott had taken over the removated the hotel so we decided to stay there again as I really liked the location and I have to say it was a completely different experience. The room was brand new and very comfortable and definitely worth the $126 a night we paid to stay there. The hotel is situated directly opposite the Glaciere Metro station on Line 6 in a quiet residential area so we found it very easy to access all the sights quickly via the metro without having to pay more exorbitant rates for less closer to the Eiffel Tower or the museums. Metro tickets were €10.90 for 10 and you could take several connecting trains if you wished on the one ticket once you didn't leave the station. The food in the hotel was excellent, if a little pricy but there are a couple of restaurants within walking distance so there was some choice in the area. This hotel is clean, comfortable and reasonable. It wouldn't be my first choice for a romantic getaway in Paris but I will definitely stay here again and would recommend it for sightseers and short business trips.

Reviews.Title: “Nice Hotel - Location Convenient, But Not Charming”
Reviews.Author: jdawwgg
Reviews.Content: After reading a couple of negative reviews, I was pretty hesitant. However, we just got back from the Rive Gauche, and I can sum it up with the word CONVENIENT. The hotel is newly redone and very nice, clean, and comfortable, but not charming or cute in a Paris-esque way. The location is great, in that it is right on top of the Metro, but, the neighborhood is generally just a basic residential neighborhood - nothing really to explore nearby. The staff are polite and competant, the consierges knowledgebale and helpful. Due to its newness and the fact that it is a recently acquired Mariott property - you can get some great deals. We stayed for under $100/night over Christmas / New Years. For a nice Mariott close to the action - that can't be beat.

Reviews.Title: “Worst Hotel Room I have EVER seen”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: As other Trip Advisor users, we got this 4 star hotel for around $140 USD with Priceline. I would have GLADLY GLADLY paid another 140 dollars just to get out of there. Fortunately it was only for one night, and we hardly used the room. The closeness to the Glaciere metro station is convenient, but not if you are looking for the Paris character, the hotel is FAR FAR away from EVERYTHING, so forget about walking. The room was dated, and SO DIRTY DIRTY DIRTY, not what you want to get after a 9 hour flight. We complained and never got an answer. The bed was just.....it can not even be called a bed. For the same amount of money, a few days later we stayed at a great boutique hotel in the Marais area. This hotel is NOT great value for you money.

Reviews.Title: “Very Nice Hotel- Good Location”
Reviews.Author: Margaret_Mary
Reviews.Content: After having read a few negative reviews of this Hotel, I wondered what four senior ladies from Florida would find. Our rooms were adequate, clean, good bathrooms, great towels, ironed sheets changed every day, carpet was worn in traffic areas, but hey, they will get around to replacing it. Many Americans were guests as well as Amer Airlines Flight Crew and other Airlines also. My one negative is the price of food..$5 for a cup of coffee, $4 for a coke, $15 for a club sandwich, needless to say we didn't buy too many of those items. Found a grocery store nearby and purchased items there, reasonably priced, like $1.20 for a coke and brought it back to our rooms. They do have a great breakfast buffet, just about everything one would want to eat and plentiful. Location is very close to a Metro Station and the Bus Stop, used both of them but most of the time we took a taxi as with 4 of us sharing, the cost was minimal. Cost about $10 to go to the attractions, Louvre, Eiffel,etc. Lunch at the Eiffel Tower was very good with a speedy entrance in with the tour we took. Most all of the personnel, understood and spoke English.Another negative is TV - French on all stations with no English captions, had to watch CNN tell me the same stories over and over all day. But hey, you don't go to Paris to watch TV. It was a good experience, while not in the heart of the attraction area, we would definitely stay there again if we were to return to Paris.

Reviews.Title: “Not too Shabby”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I read all these reviews prior to going to Paris for my first time, and expected the worst, but was surprised at how nice everything was. We stayed on the 15th floor during the holidays and had a very nice view of the city. The rooms were clean and staff (at every level) was very friendly to us non-french speaking people. We had a room mix up upon arrival (travel agency -not the hotel), and the reception desk fixed it without hesistation or attitude. The breakfast was more than expected and held my group over for most of the day. Both bar and roomservice staff were very friendly, and the food was good from both services. Though I do agree with the other reviews about the beds being hard. Almost everyone in my party complained of either back or neck problems by the 2nd day- so bring some ointment to relieve your muscles in the morning. This hotel is easy to access from both the Metro and RER (no more than 2 blocks) and the local dining is close on both sides of the hotel. All in all I would stay here again.

Reviews.Title: “Nice but you will not be pampered”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I was at the Sofitel for 4 nights. I've paid 160 euros/night through Accor's hot deals. My room was on the ninth floor with a view of the Pantheon. The room was not shining new but is ample with seating to read and a desk to work. Bathroom is quite nice, well lighted and has a bathrobe, slippers, shower cap, cotton (for make up removal probably), cotton swabs. Soap, bath gel and shampoo from Roger Gallet. There is also a sewing kit and a glove. And the Tv is big (for a hotel TV). The bed has a reading light( like in the airplanes) so you do not disturb your spouse reading at night. The hotel does not have the usual assortment of things for tourists (like the very common board with museums and entertainment advertisings). Bring in your Michelin guide red and green! The hotel restaurant (La table et la mer) is good compatible with its price (36 euros for three courses meal). The bar is nice and you can smoke your cigar there. The metro station Glaciere is near the hotel and takes you to Champs Elysees. I recommend the hotel for those that do not need much help with your tourist needs or a personal touch.
